translation.en: [Bill Basch] There is one thing that has puzzled me, and has puzzled the world…
translation.ko: 저도 이해가 안 갔지만 세계가 의아했던 점이 하나 있어요

translation.en: that the Germans dedicated manpower
and trains and trucks and energy
towards the destruction of the Jews to the last day.
translation.ko: 최후의 날까지 유대인 말살에 쏟아부었다는 점이었어요

translation.en: Had they stopped six months before the end of the war and dedicated that energy
translation.ko: 만약 종전 6개월 전에만 유대인 학살을 멈추고 그 모든 자원을

translation.en: towards strengthening themselves,
they may have carried on the war a little longer.
But it was more important to them to kill the Jews
translation.ko: 하지만 그들에게 더욱 중요했던 건 전쟁에서 이기는 게 아니라 유대인 학살이었어요

translation.en: than even winning the war.
translation.ko: 전쟁에서 이기는 게 아니라 유대인 학살이었어요

translation.en: [Irene Zisblatt] I grew up in a town called Polyana, in the Carpathian mountains.
It was a small town of two main streets.
translation.ko: 상점가 두 개가 전부인 작은 동네였죠

translation.en: This leads all the way up to… There is a church over there…
We had a post office and a town hall and a church and a synagogue.
translation.ko: 우체국 하나, 읍사무소 하나 "이레네 지스블라트 헝가리 폴랴나 출신" 정교회 성당 하나 유대교 회당 하나가 있었죠

translation.en: Everybody knew each other.
It was beautiful.
[Renee Firestone] I lived in a town called Uzhhorod.
translation.ko: "르네 파이어스톤 헝가리 우즈호로드 출신" 난 우즈호로드란 곳에 살았어요

translation.en: It was a small town,
yet it had the feel of a big, cosmopolitan town.
Right here was a little deli, right around… right here, and, uh…
translation.ko: 여기 작은 식료품점이 있었어 이 모퉁이를 돌면, 그래 여기 그리고…

translation.en: My… We used to come here to have our sandwiches for the afternoon.
[Alice Lok Cahana] We lived in a town called Sárvár.
It's in Hungary, close to the, um, Austrian border.
translation.ko: 헝가리 땅으로 "알리스 록 카하나 헝가리 샤르바르 출신" 오스트리아 국경에서 가까웠죠

translation.en: Every day, the peasants would bring their wares from the neighboring villages
translation.ko: 인근 마을 농부들이 농작물을 큰 바구니에 담아

translation.en: in big baskets, and they would carry it on their head or on their shoulders.
translation.ko: 매일 가져왔어요 머리에 이거나 어깨에 지고 왔죠

translation.en: Szaszovo was a very small, little community
translation.ko: 서소보는 아주 작은 마을로 "빌 바시 헝가리 서소보 출신"

translation.en: consisting of 3,000 people.
No electricity, no utilities at all.
translation.ko: 전기가 안 들어오고 기반 시설도 전무했던 곳이라

translation.en: So it was… I lead a very simplistic, boring life. Nothing exciting.
translation.ko: 삶이 몹시 심심하고 지루했어요 신날 일이 없었죠

translation.en: But then Budapest, where I ended up, was an entirely different life.
It was an enormous adjustment.
And I looked at this city just going, "Whoa!"
I mean, it was like… I've never believed anything like this exists!
translation.ko: 이런 세상이 있을 줄은 꿈에도 몰랐거든

translation.en: [Tom Lantos] Budapest was a magnificent, world-class city,
on par with Vienna or Paris or London as a great European capital.
translation.ko: 빈, 파리, 런던에 뒤지지 않는 "톰 랜토스 헝가리 부다페스트 출신" 유럽의 훌륭한 수도였죠

translation.en: This magnificent Parliament building
saw the best and the worst in Hungarian history.
The bulk of the Jews in Budapest
were utterly assimilated, deeply patriotic,
translation.ko: 사회와 완전히 융화돼 있었고 애국심이 투철했어요

translation.en: and enormously proud of their Hungarian cultural heritage.
translation.ko: 헝가리 문화의 후예라는 자긍심도 극에 달했죠

translation.en: There were about 800 Jewish families in our town.
And I think the town was 10,000 or 11,000 non-Jews.
translation.ko: 유대인 이외의 인구는 만 명이나 만 천 명쯤 됐죠

translation.en: I had non-Jewish friends. I dated non-Jewish boys.
translation.ko: 유대인 아닌 친구들이 있었고 유대인 아닌 남자애들도 만났어요

translation.en: My parents had non-Jewish friends.
We also felt quite Hungarian at the same time.
Not just Jewish.
So, Judaism was our religion,
but we were Hungarians.
[reporter 1] On August 2nd, 1934, officers and men swear the oath of allegiance
not to Germany, but to Hitler personally.
[reporter 2] As Hitler's rule over Germany became absolute,
to his alarmed neighbor Austria,
Hitler promised to keep hands off.
[Tom Lantos] In 1938, when I was 10 years old,
I bought my first newspaper.
And I saw the headlines,
"Hitler marches into Austria."
And I sensed that this historic moment
will have a tremendous impact on the lives of Hungarian Jews, my family, and myself.
translation.ko: 헝가리 유대인과 내 가족, 나 자신에 지대한 영향을 끼칠 것이라고요

translation.en: [reporter 3] Germany invades Poland and Danzig.
Warsaw is bombed, blasted and shelled.
Poland is in ruins.
[Renee Firestone] There were refugees coming to Hungary running away from Poland,
and most of the Jewish families, Friday night the men went to temple
translation.ko: 유대인 가정의 남자들은 대개 금요일 밤 회당에 가서

translation.en: to bring these people home and give them shelter.
translation.ko: 그 사람들을 집으로 데려와 쉬게 해줬어요

translation.en: They would come and tell stories.
And I remembered very often…
you didn't believe them.
I heard a conversation between my father and another man.
translation.ko: 아버지와 어떤 남자분이 대화를 나누고 계셨어요 "1943년의 이레네 12세"

translation.en: And he was telling my father what the Nazis are doing in Poland.
translation.ko: 폴란드에서 나치가 무슨 짓을 저질렀는지 전해주시는데

translation.en: And one thing that I'll never forget that I heard…
translation.ko: 영영 잊히지 않을 이야기가 하나 있었어요

translation.en: And he said the Nazis are taking our young Jewish infants,
translation.ko: 영영 잊히지 않을 이야기가 하나 있었어요 나치가 우리 유대인들의 어린 아기들을 데려다가

translation.en: and they're tearing them in half by their legs,
and they're throwing them in the Dniester, a river in the Ukraine.
Then later, of course,
the stories were getting worse,
and we began to hear about mass shootings and mass graves,
translation.ko: 대량 총살과 집단 매장 이야기가 들려오기 시작했죠

translation.en: But there was a sort of a naive…
I hate to use the word, but I have to use the word…
translation.ko: 이런 표현을 쓰기 싫어도 쓸 수밖에 없군요

translation.en: patriotic feeling that we Hungarians don't do such things.
translation.ko: '우리 헝가리인들'은 그런 짓을 안 하리라는 애국심이 있었죠

translation.en: Hitler was in Germany, so what happened in Germany didn't reflect on us.
translation.ko: 히틀러는 독일에 있으니 거기서 일어나는 일은 우리와 무관할 줄 알았어요

translation.en: I mean, we were far away from it.
[Randolph Braham] There were two wars.
There was a military war,
and hand-in-hand with that war.
translation.ko: 그와 동시에 벌어진 두 번째 전쟁이 있었습니다

translation.en: There was a second war,
the war of the SS directed against the Jews.
The dark side of the Hungarian national character
was becoming more and more obvious.
The persecution of Jews became more and more obvious.
Jews were losing their jobs, their businesses.
There was a Hungarian Nazi movement, the Arrow Cross,
translation.ko: 헝가리 내에 나치 주장을 표방하는 화살십자당이 생겨났고

translation.en: and this became, of course,
the most hated and the most feared group for Hungarian Jews.
translation.ko: 헝가리 유대인에게 가장 혐오스럽고 두려운 존재였죠

translation.en: [Renee Firestone] People wonder, "How is it that we didn't do something?"
translation.ko: 우리가 왜 아무 대응을 안 했는지 궁금해하는 사람들이 있어요

translation.en: We didn't run away. We didn't hide.
Well, things didn't happen at once.
Things happened very slowly,
so each time a new law came out, or a restriction,
translation.ko: 새로운 법안이나 규제가 나올 때마다 우린 그랬어요

translation.en: we said, "Well, just another thing. It'll blow over."
translation.ko: 새로운 법안이나 규제가 나올 때마다 우린 그랬어요 '뭐가 또 나왔네? 이것도 지나가겠지'

translation.en: [Tom Lantos] Hitler moved into Hungary on the 19th of March, 1944.
I was 16 years old.
1944, March 19th.
Germans entered, the SS entered, our town.
Two motorcycles was the whole Nazi regime that occupied our town
translation.ko: 우리 마을을 점령하러 온 나치 정권 병력은 오토바이 두 대가 전부였어요

translation.en: because they were there with the people that lived there the whole time
translation.ko: 일찍부터 마을에서 뒷구멍으로 일하던 사람들이 있었던 거예요

translation.en: and did their dirty.
Most of them were people we thought were our friends all these years,
translation.ko: 대다수는 우리가 오랫동안 친구라고 여겼던 사람들인데

translation.en: but they turned overnight on us
and went with the other side.
And the next restriction was
that the Jew cannot walk out on the street without the yellow star.
translation.ko: 노란 별 없는 유대인의 거리 통행을 막은 거였어요

translation.en: We heard that in Germany they to wear the yellow star
translation.ko: 나치가 독일에서 유대인을 끌고 가기 전에

translation.en: before they were taken away,
translation.ko: 노란 별을 달게 했다는 소문을 들었고

translation.en: and in Poland, they did that.
So at that point we were worried.
translation.ko: 폴란드에서도 그렇게 했기 때문에 우리도 우려를 금치 못했죠

translation.en: [Tom Lantos] I did not wear a yellow star
and I was caught.
I was put into a forced-labor camp
in a place north of Budapest,
which had an important railroad bridge.
And our job was to repair the railroads,
translation.ko: 우리가 맡은 일은 "톰과 손주들 헝가리 다뉴브강 굽이" 철도 수리였단다

translation.en: the lines, the bridges, non-stop,
translation.ko: 선로와 다리를 쉴 틈 없이 고쳤어

translation.en: while the British and the Americans were bombing day and night.
We were obviously worried that we would die.
But we were also hoping
that the American and British bombers will hit all of their targets
translation.ko: 미국, 영국 폭격기가 모든 표적을 정확히 타격하고

translation.en: and destroy this bridge
because that was the way to defeat Hitler.
I escaped from that labor camp,
and I joined the Hungarian underground.
And the next decree would be that we have to pack up 25 kilos.
translation.ko: 다음 법령이 발표됐는데 우리더러 짐을 싸래요 최대 25kg까지요

translation.en: And at first, we didn't understand. What do you take?
translation.ko: 처음에는 실감이 안 났죠 뭘 가져가지?

translation.en: Think about your home, your own home.
What would you take, 25 kilos?
What is 25 kilos?
How much is 25 kilos?
Do you take the pillows? Your covers?
Do you take your dishes? Do you take…
What do you take?
When we were packing,
I wanted to take something that would remind me of the good times.
translation.ko: 좋은 추억이 떠오르는 물건을 가져가고 싶었어요

translation.en: I was very depressed and worried.
And so I came across a bathing suit.
A bathing suit that my father brought me.
I don't want to do this.
On one of his business trips, about three years earlier,
my father came home.
And, um… he always brought us something, my sister and myself.
translation.ko: 아버지는 항상 선물을 가져다가 저희 자매에게 주셨죠

translation.en: And, uh…
of course, we always asked, "What did you bring?"
And he opened this box,
and out of the box came this most beautiful bathing suit.
translation.ko: 세상에서 제일 예쁜 수영복이 상자에서 나왔어요

translation.en: It had a shiny satin finish
translation.ko: 반짝이는 새틴으로 마무리됐고 알록달록한 꽃무늬 프린트였죠

translation.en: and a print of multicolored flowers.
translation.ko: 반짝이는 새틴으로 마무리됐고 알록달록한 꽃무늬 프린트였죠 "1943년의 르네(오른쪽) 19세"

translation.en: And then in the afternoon, when I heard the soldiers' boots coming up the stairs,
translation.ko: 그날 오후에 계단을 올라오는 군홧발 소리가 들렸어요

translation.en: I ran back, and I put this bathing suit under my dress.
translation.ko: 난 뛰어 들어가서 원피스 안에 그 수영복을 입었죠

translation.en: And that's how I left.
They broke down the front doors. They came in. They gave us a few minutes.
translation.ko: 현관문을 부수고 집에 들어와 몇 분의 시간을 줬어요

translation.en: They said a half hour, but it was not a half hour,
translation.ko: 말은 30분이라고 했지만 절대 그렇게 안 줬죠

translation.en: to get it all our valuables together,
and they… They marched us out of the house.
I couldn't imagine that they just take out people from their homes…
translation.ko: 살던 집에서 끌려 나간다는 건 상상이 안 가는 일이었어요

translation.en: because they're Jewish.
Our friends, so-called, and neighbors,
they were standing lined up alongside of the road,
and they were yelling,
"It's about time, you go on out of here. And we don't need any Jews in our town."
translation.ko: '당신들 그만 나갈 때도 됐어' '우리 동네에 유대인은 한 명도 필요 없어'

translation.en: "We need to get rid of all you Jews."
I stood, and I could not believe my eyes.
[hesitates] The people I went to school with their children. We were friends.
translation.ko: 같은 학교에 다니는 아이들의 부모님이었어요 우린 친구였고 뭐든 나누며 살았는데

translation.en: We were sharing things together.
Why are they so hostile? Why do they hate us all of a sudden?
translation.ko: 왜 저렇게 적대적이지? 왜 갑자기 우릴 미워해?

translation.en: It's like when you read that the Jews went out of Egypt.
translation.ko: 유대인이 이집트를 떠나던 구절을 읽는 것 같았어요

translation.en: We are carrying all our baggage.
The pillows and the covers are tied to them, bundled.
And we children helped to carry. And I'm so ashamed.
translation.ko: 아이들도 짐 옮기는 걸 돕는데 너무나 창피했어요

translation.en: [Renee Firestone] We wanted to believe they're gonna take us to Germany.
translation.ko: 우리를 독일로 데려가 일을 시킬 거라고 생각했어요

translation.en: And we're gonna work. We really wanted to believe it.
translation.ko: 우리를 독일로 데려가 일을 시킬 거라고 생각했어요 정말 그렇게 믿고 싶었어요

translation.en: And by then, the whole European Jewry was already in camps,
translation.ko: 그때 유럽의 유대인들은 모두 수용소에 갇혀 있었는데

translation.en: which we didn't know.
The concentration, ghettoization and deportation
took place in a concentrated manner that is within 12 weeks.
And nowhere else was the deportation program carried out
translation.ko: 하지만 그 어느 곳도 추방 작전을 시행함에 있어

translation.en: with the barbarity and speed that it was in Hungary.
They say that they will take us to a ghetto,
and we'd never heard that word.
It is not a Hungarian word, "ghetto."
[Renee Firestone] We had no idea where we were.
In the morning, when we woke up,
I realized that we are in a brickyard.
Brick factory yard.
And in April, it was rainy. It was a lot of rain.
translation.ko: 4월인데 비가 많이 내렸어 "이레네와 딸 로빈 문카치 강제거주지역 유적"

translation.en: And we were always…
translation.ko: "이레네와 딸 로빈 문카치 강제거주지역 유적" 그래서 우린 늘 천을 바꿔 널었어 지붕 대신 천을 덮었거든

translation.en: We had to change the sheet because the roof was the sheet,
translation.ko: 그래서 우린 늘 천을 바꿔 널었어 지붕 대신 천을 덮었거든

translation.en: and we were always wet.
There were thousands of people there because they came from the whole county.
translation.ko: 군 단위에서 잡혀 온 사람을 전부 모아 놓으니 수천 명이었어요

translation.en: And there were guards everywhere, with dogs,
walking around all the time, big German Shepherd dogs,
translation.ko: 덩치 큰 독일셰퍼드를 끌고 24시간 내내 순찰을 돌았죠

translation.en: on very, very tight leashes.
…because this was all these huts, with people, people all over the place.
[Robin] Do you know where your hut was?
[Irene Zisblatt] Yes. My hut was right here, where these piles of bricks are.
translation.ko: - 천막 있던 자리는 기억나세요? - 그럼 내 막사는 벽돌 쌓여 있는 바로 이 자리에 있었어

translation.en: [sniffles] And then one day they announced
that everybody that wants to go to work to Tokay
translation.ko: 어느 날 놈들이 발표했어요 토카이의 포도밭에 가서 포도주 만드는 일을 할 사람은

translation.en: on the vineyard to make wine should come here,
translation.ko: 토카이의 포도밭에 가서 포도주 만드는 일을 할 사람은 다 나오라고요

translation.en: and everybody voluntary, gladly went on the train
translation.ko: 그랬더니 다들 자원해서 기꺼이 기차에 올라탔죠

translation.en: because this was hell.
And going to work in a vineyard was like going to heaven from this.
translation.ko: 벽돌 공장에 비하면 포도밭은 천국 같았죠

translation.en: We were taken to the railroad station by the Hungarian soldiers.
My mother said to me,
"I rolled up diamonds in your skirt, in the hem of your skirt."
"And if you don't have enough to eat, those are to buy bread."
When we arrived at the railroad station,
we realized that we're not going on passenger trains.
translation.ko: 객차에 탈 수 없다는 걸 알아차렸어요

translation.en: The cattle cars were waiting for us.
[Irene Zisblatt] My father said, "They ran out of other trains because it's wartime."
translation.ko: 아버지는 전쟁 중이라 기차가 부족한 거라고 하셨어요

translation.en: "They don't have the other train. So, they have to use what they have."
translation.ko: 다른 차량이 없으니 이거라도 써야 한다고요

translation.en: [Alice Lok Cahana] Anybody who didn't go and didn't go fast was beaten.
When they closed the doors, then I heard that knock on the outside
translation.ko: 열차 문을 닫으니까 밖에서 철컹 소리가 났어요

translation.en: like a bolt closing us in there.
translation.ko: 빗장을 질러 우리를 가두는 소리 같았죠

translation.en: It wasn't normal anymore. It wasn't…
I didn't accept that they were running out of the other trains.
translation.ko: 차량이 부족해 거기에 태웠다고는 생각되지 않았어요

translation.en: [Bill Basch] In Budapest, this time started getting worse.
I really had to acquire Gentile papers.
I did not exist as a Jew.
I would have been shot. I would have been killed.
You were a hunted animal, 24 hours, every day,
and you didn't know if anybody you encountered
was really on your side.
translation.ko: 진짜 내 편인지 알 수 없었죠

translation.en: Had it not been for Wallenberg,
neither I nor the other tens of thousands would have ever survived.
translation.ko: 저를 비롯해 수천 명의 유대인이 살아남지 못했을 겁니다

translation.en: Raoul Wallenberg arrived when all of Hungary,
with the exception of Budapest, was already free of Jews.
translation.ko: 부다페스트 이외 지역에 유대인이 하나도 없었어요

translation.en: He went to Budapest at a time when, in the countryside,
the Jews had already been put into cattle cars
translation.ko: 외곽 지역의 유대인은 이미 가축 수송차에 실려

translation.en: and shipped away from Hungary.
And he decided to join the Swedish embassy there
translation.ko: 그 사람은 오로지 유대인을 구할 목적으로

translation.en: for the sole purpose of trying to save Jewish lives.
By issuing so-called Swedish protective passports,
he declared that the individual who had this document
at the end of the war planned to go to Sweden.
translation.ko: 전쟁이 끝나면 스웨덴으로 갈 자국인이라고 주장했어요

translation.en: This was pure fiction, but in the chaos and the confusion of the war,
translation.ko: 다 지어낸 얘기였지만 전쟁의 혼란과 무질서 속에서

translation.en: this miraculous, worthless piece of paper worked.
translation.ko: 기적과도 같은 한낱 종이 한 장이 위력을 발휘했어요

translation.en: [Bill Basch] Several of us acted as distributors or runners
translation.ko: 우리 중 몇몇은 서류 운반자 또는 심부름꾼으로 활동하며

translation.en: to deliver this fake passport
to the people that were waiting in those protected houses.
[Tom Lantos] Wallenberg leased large apartment houses,
translation.ko: 발렌베리는 대형 아파트 건물을 여러 채 빌려

translation.en: put up a Swedish sign indicating that all the residents
translation.ko: 스웨덴어 표지판을 세웠어요 이곳의 거주자 전원이

translation.en: were under the protection of the royal Swedish government.
translation.ko: 스웨덴 왕국 정부의 보호 아래 있다는 내용이었죠

translation.en: I stayed at St. Stephen Park, number 25.
Most of these houses were upper-middle-class apartment houses,
and a three-bedroom apartment,
that may have had four, five, six people living there before this crisis,
suddenly became a hovel
with 60, 70 people jammed into a three-bedroom apartment.
translation.ko: 방 세 칸에 60~70명이 발 디딜 틈 없이 지냈죠

translation.en: [girl 1] Very uncomfortable.
It was very uncomfortable, honey,
but more importantly, it was unbelievably dangerous.
The word "protected house" obviously is a misnomer,
uh, because many of the people living in these quote-unquote "protected houses"
translation.ko: 이른바 '안전 가옥'이란 곳에서 살던 수많은 이들이 체포당했고

translation.en: were rounded up, taken to the bank of the Danube, and killed.
translation.ko: 이른바 '안전 가옥'이란 곳에서 살던 수많은 이들이 체포당했고 다뉴브 강둑으로 끌려가 처형당했거든요

translation.en: Now, to get into the protected houses was not difficult.
translation.ko: 안전 가옥 안에 들어가는 건 어렵지 않았어요

translation.en: Soldiers didn't care.
They were out in the front. "Go in there."
translation.ko: 건물 앞에 서 있었지만 들어가라고 했어요

translation.en: However, to come out
that was the very, very difficult thing.
If German soldiers or Hungarian Nazi soldiers were suspicious,
translation.ko: 독일군이나 헝가리 나치군은 뭔가 수상하다 싶으면

translation.en: they ordered us to take down our pants
because we were the only people who were circumcised.
One day, I had on my body, strapped around, the fake passports,
translation.ko: 하루는 위조 여권을 몸에 두른 채로

translation.en: which I was delivering to these people so they could get out of the building,
translation.ko: 사람들이 건물 밖으로 나오도록 배달을 하러 다니다가

translation.en: and I miscalculated.
I went through the sewer line, and I knew when to get out.
translation.ko: 보통은 하수도로 이동하다가 언제 나가야 하는지 아는데

translation.en: And I made a mistake,
instead of coming out in the middle of the building,
I came out in front of the building,
where two soldiers were guarding the building.
translation.ko: 군인 둘이 앞에서 보초를 서고 있었죠

translation.en: I started running as fast as I could,
crossing the street back and forth.
And they were deporting a group of Jews,
translation.ko: 그때 추방당하던 유대인 한 무리가 있었어요

translation.en: not knowing where they're taking them,
I jumped into that group of Jews thinking,
"As I got in so many times into trouble, I'll get out one more time."
translation.ko: '아슬아슬했던 게 한두 번인가? 이번에도 잘 빠져나갈 거야'

translation.en: "Just one more escape."
We would up five days later in Buchenwald.
[Irene Zisblatt] We were on the train for about five days.
Sitting on a heap of luggage that we carried there.
translation.ko: 우리가 들고 간 짐 더미에 앉아서 갔죠

translation.en: The cattle car that I was in, there was about 120 of us.
translation.ko: 제가 탔던 가축 수송 칸에 120명이 있었어요

translation.en: Mashed together like sardines, and it's very, very hot.
translation.ko: 통조림 생선처럼 밀착해 있었고 지독하게 더웠어요

translation.en: They had one pail, you know, for going to the bathroom.
And suddenly the buckets filled up, and then the odor was unbearable.
translation.ko: 순간에 통이 차면서 견딜 수 없는 악취가 풍겼죠

translation.en: They never opened the doors to go to the bathroom.
They never gave us any water. They never gave us any food.
The children were screaming. They wanted to go home.
"Where are they taking us? Where are they taking us?"
Nobody answered.
It was total darkness.
The light seeped only through the cracks of the cattle car.
translation.ko: 가축 수송차의 틈새로 새어 들어오는 빛이 전부였죠

translation.en: [Irene Zisblatt] My father found a crack in the cattle train.
He looked out, and he spoke out loud,
"I don't think we're going to the vineyard
translation.ko: '원래 보내준다던 포도밭으로 가는 게 아닌가 보다'

translation.en: because we just crossed the border, and we're heading towards Poland."
translation.ko: '방금 국경을 넘었고 폴란드를 향해 가고 있어'

translation.en: When he said Poland,
I remembered the man telling the story about the children,
what they're doing to the children in Poland.
And I was holding my little brother. He was two-and-a-half years old.
translation.ko: 남동생을 안고 있었는데 두 살 반이던 그 아이를

translation.en: I was holding him so tight.
And I said to him, I said to myself,
"I will never let him go. They will never take him from me."
translation.ko: '너를 절대로 놓지 않을게 데려가지 못하게 지킬 거야'

translation.en: When they opened the door suddenly…
and suddenly the light hit you.
And because you had your eyes for four, five days shut,
or used to this darkness,
you're almost blinded.
We were so happy because we were going to get air.
translation.ko: 숨을 쉴 수 있으니까 굉장히 행복했어요

translation.en: We were gonna get off, go to the bathroom like normal people,
translation.ko: 기차에서 내려서 보통 사람처럼 화장실에 가겠구나

translation.en: and have water and maybe some food.
translation.ko: 물도 마시고 음식도 먹을 줄 알았어요

translation.en: And everybody would ask, "Where are we? What's the name?"
And it was very strange name.
Auschwitz.
[Alice Lok Cahana] Here, we had to be stopped.
Here was… A lot of selection happened.
-You're all standing in a line-- -Thousands of people,
close to each other,
and confusion and noise.
And then… Don't move, and don't… [snaps fingers]
Like soldiers standing straight, you see?
And in the middle would the SS go here,
to check all of us.
Walking the dogs and just threatening.
-Single file, or people standing next to… -Five.
[Michael] Five in a row.
[Alice Lok Cahana] So it was easy to count, right.
[Renee Firestone] When I jumped off the cattle car,
I knew right away that whatever they promised us,
translation.ko: 그들이 했던 약속도 그들이 했던 말도

translation.en: whatever they told us, were lies.
And you see a lot of people running in striped clothes and shaved heads.
translation.ko: 줄무늬 옷에 삭발한 사람들이 수도 없이 뛰어다니는 게 보여요

translation.en: Surrounded by Nazi soldiers and vicious dogs.
translation.ko: 나치 군인과 사나운 개들이 우리를 둘러쌌어요

translation.en: And they were yelling, and they were screaming.
"Hurry up! Leave all your luggage there. Just leave everything."
translation.ko: '서둘러! 짐은 그대로 둬 다 놓고 간다!'

translation.en: All of a sudden, there was a separation,
and my mother and my…
my mother and… [exhales]
and my brother and my sister…
She held my little brother in her arms, in one arm,
translation.ko: 어머니는 남동생을 품에 안고 한 손으론 4살 반짜리 여동생 손을 잡으셨고

translation.en: and my four-and-a-half-year-old sister in her hand. I was holding onto her hand.
translation.ko: 한 손으론 4살 반짜리 여동생 손을 잡으셨고 전 그 손을 꼭 붙잡았어요

translation.en: This is how we were walking towards…
They were pushing us towards that destination.
[in German] When the transports came in,
the people were sorted.
translation.ko: 사람들을 분류하는 작업이 이뤄졌어요 "한스 뮌히 박사 전직 아우슈비츠 나치 의사"

translation.en: It was a very basic process, a very simple one.
translation.ko: "한스 뮌히 박사 전직 아우슈비츠 나치 의사" 아주 단순명료한 작업이었어요

translation.en: The people had to stand in a long line.
At the front of the line were some medical officers who would say,
translation.ko: 줄의 맨 앞에는 의료 장교들이 있었어요

translation.en: "This one’s too old, over 50."
"This one goes to the right. The other goes left."
[Renee Firestone] My mother was selected at the railroad station,
going to the left while my sister and I went to the right.
translation.ko: 어머니는 왼쪽으로 가고 저와 여동생은 오른쪽으로 갔어요

translation.en: My mother was taken straight from the railroad station to the gas chambers.
By the time my sister and I were processed into the camp,
my mother was no longer alive.
[Renee Firestone] We were taken to a dressing room.
We were told we're gonna be taking a shower after this…
after this horrendous journey,
and we are going to refresh ourselves,
and then we will be assigned to our work.
[Irene Zisblatt] They ordered us to take our shoes in one hand and our clothes in the other.
translation.ko: 우리한테 신발과 옷을 벗어 양손에 들라고 했어요

translation.en: And I remembered the diamonds.
And I grabbed my blue skirt, and in the crowd, you know,
translation.ko: 내 파란 치마를 움켜쥐고 사람들 다 있는 데서

translation.en: I just fast took out the diamonds and held them in my hands,
translation.ko: 다이아몬드를 재빨리 꺼낸 후 손에 쥐고 있었어요

translation.en: and I had no clothes on my body.
And I remember I got undressed with the rest of them,
translation.ko: 다른 사람들이랑 같이 옷을 벗었던 게 기억나요

translation.en: and there I was in the bathing suit, standing in the bathing suit.
I had a premonition.
I had this feeling that if I take this bathing suit off,
if I leave this bathing suit behind,
all the wonderful memories that were built in this bathing suit…
translation.ko: 그걸 입고 쌓았던 아름다운 추억들은 모두…

translation.en: I kept remembering how I walked around the swimming pool,
translation.ko: 수영복 차림으로 수영장에서 돌아다니던 모습이 떠올랐어요

translation.en: and how the boys were whistling at me, and my friends were so jealous.
translation.ko: "르네(가운데)" 휘파람 불던 남자애들과 그토록 질투하던 친구들도요

translation.en: And now I'm going to take it off, and I'm going to leave it here.
translation.ko: 수영복을 벗으면 여기 내려놓고 가야 하는데

translation.en: Everything that meant anything in life to me, I'm going to leave behind.
translation.ko: 내 인생에서 의미 있었던 모든 걸 내려놓아야 한다는 뜻이었죠

translation.en: [Irene] They kept on saying
if anybody has any valuables left, to leave them.
translation.ko: 귀중품이 있는 사람은 보관 장소에 놓고 가라고요

translation.en: They had a section for that. [sniffles]
I held onto the diamonds for dear life because that was to buy bread.
translation.ko: 난 다이아몬드를 놓을 수 없었어요 빵을 사야 하니까요

translation.en: So I put them in my mouth.
And then when I walked up again,
I saw they were opening people's mouths, and they were looking in,
translation.ko: 사람들 입을 열어서 검사하는 게 보였어요

translation.en: but I was in the… I was, like, at the at the road of no return.
I couldn't give 'em up any more because I would be shot.
translation.ko: 이제 와서 내놓으면 총살을 당할 테니까요

translation.en: Why didn't I leave 'em back there?
And I had them in my mouth,
and I didn't know what to do, so I swallowed them.
We walked into the shower room,
and the dressing room was locked behind us,
and a commando came in and removed all our belongings right away.
translation.ko: 특공대가 하나 들어오더니 우리 소지품을 즉각 압수했어요

translation.en: They did give us a shower, a little, trinkly shower, and then they…
translation.ko: 샤워를 시켜주긴 했어요 물을 쫄쫄쫄 흘려주고 나서는

translation.en: Again, there was a door on the other side
leading out to the courtyard on the other side of this building.
And at the door, they had a pile of clothes.
translation.ko: 그 문 앞에 옷이 수북이 쌓여 있는데

translation.en: And they ordered everybody to pick one piece of clothing.
translation.ko: 누구나 딱 한 개만 집으라고 명령했어요

translation.en: We waited till about midnight,
then they permitted us to walk into one of these wooden barracks.
[Alice Lok Cahana] A thousand people in a barrack.
If one person turned, everybody had to turn
translation.ko: 한 명이 돌아누우면 전원이 다 돌아누워야 했지

translation.en: because we were so close to each other.
I used to wake up so cold,
and I…
used to have returning dreams
that I'm at home,
that I'm very cold,
but my father will come and comfort me, so…
And then, you wake up.
From a whistle.
It's dark outside.
And this is a madman's hell.
[Renee Firestone] We saw this group of about 20 men coming through the camp,
translation.ko: 스무 명 남짓한 남자들이 수용소를 통과하는 게 보였어요

translation.en: and as they were marching by, I was watching.
Maybe I know somebody.
And suddenly, I recognize my father.
And my first thought was to hide.
It was terribly painful seeing him
with his shaved head and his uniform, like a prisoner.
translation.ko: 머리는 박박 깎았고 죄수처럼 제복을 입고 계셨죠

translation.en: This man who was helping everybody,
who was the kindest human being.
I just couldn't imagine how would he feel if he saw us
translation.ko: 우리 꼴을 보면 어떤 기분이실지 상상이 안 됐어요

translation.en: with the shaved heads and in this rag.
So I really just wanted to hide so he can't see me.
translation.ko: 쥐구멍에라도 들어가 아버지 눈을 피하고 싶었죠

translation.en: And at that moment, our eyes locked.
And I could see his tears rolling down his cheek.
That was the last time I saw my father.
[Irene Zisblatt] I saw trucks coming
and screams in the trucks.
And I saw two children fall out of the truck.
translation.ko: 아이들 둘이 트럭에서 떨어지는 걸 봤어요

translation.en: [Irene] And the truck stopped,
[Irene Zisblatt] And the trucks [hesitates]…
And one SS man came out from the front,
and he picked up the children… [sniffs] …like that.
And he banged him against the truck,
and the blood came running down, and threw him into the truck, so…
translation.ko: 피가 줄줄 흐르는데 아이를 트럭에 던졌죠

translation.en: That's when I stopped talking to God.
They told us that we're gonna get a number.
Prisoner's number.
Well, of course, we expected to get a prisoner's number
translation.ko: 죄수 번호를 붙여줄 거라고 예상은 했었어요

translation.en: on our clothing or somewhere.
And they set up these tables.
And at each table sat a few guards
with huge books open in front of them.
And we presumed that they are going to put our name in it,
and the number that they're going to give us.
And then we realized that they are putting this number
on our flesh,
on our arms.
They took five of us and put drops in our eyes.
translation.ko: 우리 중 다섯 명을 데려가 눈에 약을 넣었어요

translation.en: We didn't know why. They didn't tell us. And they put us in the dungeon.
translation.ko: 이유는 몰랐죠, 말도 안 해줬고요 그러더니 지하 감옥에 넣었어요

translation.en: They closed us in there,
and we were standing in water up to our ankles, tightly packed,
translation.ko: 발목까지 물이 찬 방에 사람들이 빽빽이 서 있는데

translation.en: and it seemed like forever.
It seemed like it was an eternity. They never opened the door.
translation.ko: 한없이 시간만 가는데 문은 절대 열어주지 않았고

translation.en: They never gave us anything to eat or drink.
translation.ko: 먹을 것, 마실 것도 아예 주지 않았어요

translation.en: So, we drank the water we stood in.
translation.ko: 그래서 발을 담그고 있던 물을 마셨고

translation.en: We went to the bathroom in the water we stood in.
translation.ko: 그 물에 선 채로 볼일을 봤어요

translation.en: And then they opened the door, and they took us out.
And they brought us up into the courtyard,
and they examined our eyes.
And some of the people couldn't see for several days after that.
translation.ko: 몇몇 사람은 그 후 며칠 동안 시력을 잃었어요

translation.en: And they took us back to the barrack.
And then we found out later what they were doing.
translation.ko: 우리한테 무슨 짓을 했는지는 나중에 알았어요

translation.en: They were trying to change the color of our eyes.
[in German] For those who wanted to conduct experiments on humans,
this was a useful workplace.
Many experiments were done in Auschwitz to find ways to sterilize women,
translation.ko: 아우슈비츠에서는 다양한 실험이 이뤄졌어요 여성 불임 실험이 많았죠

translation.en: specifically Jewish women, in order to diminish the race
translation.ko: 특히 유대인 여성의 임신을 막으면 복잡한 절차 없이

translation.en: without going through too much trouble.
These women were then sent back to the camp.
translation.ko: 여성들을 실험 대상으로 쓴 후에는 수용소로 돌려보냈어요

translation.en: Sometimes they were immediately transferred
translation.ko: 다른 수용소로 곧장 이송할 때도 있었어요

translation.en: because they were so-called "secret bearers."
They performed tests, then sent them back to Birkenau and gassed them.
translation.ko: 실험을 마치면 비르케나우로 돌려보내 가스실에서 처형했어요

translation.en: One day, a prisoner acquaintance came to me and asked me
translation.ko: 하루는 안면이 있던 수감자가 찾아와서 부탁했어요

translation.en: if I could try to gain some influence…
if anything could be done, not to send them to the gas chamber.
translation.ko: 뭐든지 좋으니까 가스실만은 보내지 말아 달라고 했어요

translation.en: The only way to do that was to make them undergo more tests.
translation.ko: 가스실에 안 보낼 방법은 실험을 더 하는 것밖에 없었죠

translation.en: To save them, we had to keep conducting harmless tests on them.
translation.ko: 인체에 무해한 실험을 계속해야만 그들을 구할 수 있었어요

translation.en: This is what we planned to do, and somehow it worked.
translation.ko: 그런 계획을 짰는데 어찌 된 일인지 효과가 있었죠

translation.en: And that is why I was acquitted…
in Auschwitz.
[Randolph] Having survived the first four and a half years of the war,
translation.ko: 전쟁 발발 후 4년 반을 버텼던 헝가리 유대인들은

translation.en: the Hungarian Jews were killed in the last chapter
translation.ko: 전쟁 발발 후 4년 반을 버텼던 헝가리 유대인들은 히틀러의 유대인 말살 전쟁 막바지에 처형당했는데

translation.en: of Hitler's war against the Jews when the leaders of the world
translation.ko: 히틀러의 유대인 말살 전쟁 막바지에 처형당했는데 세계 지도자들은 이미 아우슈비츠의 실상을

translation.en: were already fully aware of all the details of Auschwitz.
translation.ko: 세계 지도자들은 이미 아우슈비츠의 실상을 철저히 파악하고 있었어요

translation.en: When we came to Auschwitz,
it was during the Final Solution,
when he just was desperate already.
He was losing the war. Hitler was losing the war,
but he was not going to lose the war against the Jews.
translation.ko: 유대인 상대 전쟁에서는 패할 생각이 없었죠

translation.en: The sadism, the cruelty,
the irrationality of the German and Hungarian Nazis,
of killing the remaining Jewish population when the war was all over,
translation.ko: 전쟁이 다 끝나가는 판에도 남은 유대인 몰살에 집중했어요

translation.en: when they could have gained brownie points
translation.ko: 조금 더 세련된 방식으로 유대인을 다뤘다면

translation.en: by being more civilized vis-à-vis these people,
was really not present because their hatred was so blind.
translation.ko: 증오에 눈이 멀어 그럴 생각조차 못 했죠

translation.en: [Randolph Braham] The Nazis diverted trains and other transportation means useful to the Germans
translation.ko: 나치는 독일군이 요긴하게 사용할 철도와 여타 교통수단을

translation.en: for purposes of deporting Jews, to complete the Final Solution program.
translation.ko: 유대인 추방 목적으로 전용해 최종 해결책 수행에 사용했어요

translation.en: While I was in Auschwitz,
the transports were coming in two, three transports a day,
with thousands of people in it.
[Randolph Braham] Within less than six weeks,
more than 438,000 Hungarian Jews
were deported to Auschwitz.
The gas chambers, the crematoria, could not cope.
translation.ko: 기존 가스실과 화장장으로는 감당이 안 돼서

translation.en: The SS had to dig special pits
to burn the bodies,
using the Jews' own fat as fuel.
translation.ko: 유대인 몸에서 나온 지방을 연료로 썼죠

translation.en: I saw how they were throwing people into these fire pits.
translation.ko: 사람을 불구덩이에 던지는 모습을 제 눈으로 봤어요

translation.en: And I said to myself, "Something is wrong with me. My mind is going."
translation.ko: 전 그랬죠, '나 어떻게 됐나 봐 제정신이 아닌 것 같아'

translation.en: I couldn't be seeing this.
[in German] The mass graves were
about eight by ten or ten by ten meters wide.
Wood was piled on the bottom and set on fire.
Then the bodies were thrown over the fire. That was it.
translation.ko: 거기서 불이 타오르면 시신을 던져 넣고 끝이에요

translation.en: If the fat burned, then the grave was working.
translation.ko: 지방이 타기 시작하면 무덤이 제대로 가동되죠

translation.en: Then more and more bodies were thrown into it.
That simple.
[Alice Lok Cahana] What vast landscape you are seeing here.
How could people, normal people, go back
translation.ko: 어떻게 평범한 사람으로 돌아갈 수 있지?

translation.en: after working here,
or planned this, okay?
Somebody had to plan it.
Somebody had to be an engineer.
Somebody had to really put on a map, this kind of efficiency.
translation.ko: 이런 엄청난 시설을 지으려면 철저한 계획 감독이 필요했을 거야

translation.en: But the whole time I was in the camp, through the experiment,
translation.ko: 수용소에서 지내며 실험 대상으로 쓰이는 동안

translation.en: every time I was selected, I swallowed the diamonds.
So, every time I swallowed them, I had to find them again.
translation.ko: 매번 삼킬 때마다 다시 찾아야 했고요

translation.en: We were allowed to go to the latrine once a day,
translation.ko: 야외 변소 사용은 하루에 한 번만 허락됐어요

translation.en: and I never sat on the hole because I had to go and find my diamonds.
translation.ko: 난 다이아몬드를 찾아야 하니까 절대로 배출구에 앉지 않았죠

translation.en: And when the SS woman walked by the door, and she saw me in the corner…
translation.ko: 하루는 여자 친위대원이 문 앞을 지나가다가 구석의 나를 봤어요

translation.en: I already had the diamonds in hand. Usually I was waiting until…
translation.ko: 다이아몬드를 손에 넣었을 때였죠 보통은 기다렸다가

translation.en: On the way back, I would rinse them off, like in the mud,
or if there was no mud,
in the soup that we were going to get next,
but I had no time, and I had to swallow them.
My God, this is the latrine.
Oh my God.
At this place, I was with my sister,
translation.ko: 여기서 우리 언니 이디스 옆에 앉을 수 있었어

translation.en: with Edith next to me.
translation.ko: 우리 언니 이디스 옆에 앉을 수 있었어

translation.en: And so Edith whispers to me and says,
"It's almost Shabbat. It's Friday. It's almost Shabbat."
translation.ko: '곧 안식일이야, 오늘은 금요일 곧 안식일이 와'

translation.en: How we used to celebrate Shabbat in our house,
with food and with singing and with praying
and, you know, lighting the candle.
And I told her, "Why don't we celebrate inside, in the latrine?"
translation.ko: 내가 언니한테 그랬어 '이 변소에서 안식일을 지킬까?'

translation.en: We ran back to the end, and we started to make our Shabbat ceremony,
translation.ko: 저 끝으로 뛰어가서 우리끼리 안식일 축제를 시작했어

translation.en: and we started to sing.
And as we sang the melody,
other children came around us and started to sing with us.
translation.ko: 다른 아이들이 우리 옆에 와서 같이 노래하기 시작했어

translation.en: Somebody was from Holland. Somebody was from Germany.
translation.ko: 네덜란드에서 온 아이도 있고 독일에서 온 아이도 있었어

translation.en: Somebody was from Hungary, Czechoslovakia. All thrown together.
translation.ko: 헝가리, 체코슬로바키아에서 온 아이들이 함께 어우러져서

translation.en: And suddenly, the Hebrew songs, the prayers, the Shabbat,
translation.ko: 히브리어 노래를 부르고 기도하고 안식일을 지키며

translation.en: united us in the latrine of Auschwitz.
[Irene Zisblatt] People couldn't endure all this pain,
the conditions and the hunger and the lice.
The lice were, like, as big as my pinky nail,
embedded into our bodies.
And we were sore from scratching and infections.
And so, when the electricity went on,
they ran to the barbed wire to commit suicide.
translation.ko: 전기 철조망에 달려가 자살하는 사람도 있었어요

translation.en: Then they punished us. For every man that ran to the wire,
translation.ko: 누가 철조망으로 달려갈 때마다 우리가 벌을 받았어요

translation.en: they took 100 inmates,
and they killed them in front of everybody as an example.
translation.ko: 다들 보는 앞에서 처형해 본보기로 삼았죠

translation.en: They didn't even let us die when we wanted.
translation.ko: 죽고 싶을 때 죽지도 못하게 했죠

translation.en: And then I thought of something.
They took away my parents.
They took away my identity.
They took away my siblings.
They took away my possessions.
There is something that they want from me.
And then I thought of my soul.
And I said, "They're not gonna take my soul."
And I decided right then and there,
"I'm going to get up from this mud, and I'm going to fight
because I'm not going to become ashes."
[Renee Firestone] When we arrived to Auschwitz,
thousands and thousands of people were cremated every day.
translation.ko: 매일 셀 수 없이 많은 사람이 화장당했어요

translation.en: The Nazis used Jewish inmates,
a special Sonderkommando,
to remove the bodies from the gas chambers
and take the bodies into the crematoria.
As far as I know, there is only four of us
that worked in the Sonderkommando alive today.
translation.ko: 저를 포함해 네 명이 전부인 걸로 압니다 "다리오 가바이 아우슈비츠 존더코만도"

translation.en: And we are the only eyewitness
that saw the whole thing from A to Z.
How the Final Solution was done.
I'm Jewish, from Greece.
And I lived in Greece until the time they took me to concentration camp.
The first week of April 1944,
I arrived in Auschwitz.
They selected some of the Greeks to go to work in crematorium.
translation.ko: 놈들은 화장장에서 일할 그리스 사람을 몇 명 선발했어요

translation.en: Now is my first day there.
I don't know what was going on.
I saw 2,500 people, all naked,
go into the big chamber, which eventually…
They take only 500 people. They were putting in 2,500 people.
So nobody could do anything but stand by their children.
translation.ko: 다들 꼼짝없이 자식들 옆에 서 있었어요

translation.en: And 15 minutes later, you know, after they close the chambers,
and the SS threw the gas from these four openings,
you know, they open up.
What did I see? I see the people I saw 15 minutes ago.
translation.ko: 분명 15분 전만 해도 제 눈앞에 있던 사람들이

translation.en: I see them all dead, standing up, with their children black and blue.
translation.ko: 전부 아이들과 함께 선 채로 죽어 검푸르게 변해 있었어요

translation.en: And I said to myself, "What's going on? What's going on here?"
translation.ko: 난 혼잣말을 했죠 '무슨 일이 벌어지는 거지?'

translation.en: There was a Polish guy that was there before,
translation.ko: 저보다 먼저 온 폴란드 남자가 하나 있었는데

translation.en: and I said, "Where is God?"
He said, "God, God is where you have your strength."
translation.ko: 그 사람이 말했죠 '네가 힘을 내야 하느님이 오셔'

translation.en: There were four crematoriums, you know, and they were working 24 hours.
And there were a lot of big shots from Berlin
coming and watching how the Jews were dying.
You know, there was a hole, in the, you know, hermetically closed,
translation.ko: 완전히 밀폐된 작고 둥근 창을 통해

translation.en: and they were looking there how the Jewish people were dying.
Takes two to four minutes. Depends where you are.
A lot of people think that we, working in the Sonderkommando,
translation.ko: 특공대로 일했던 우리에게도 죄가 있다고 생각하는 분들이

translation.en: we were guilty of something because we were doing such kind of work.
translation.ko: 많다는 걸 압니다 실무를 우리가 했으니까요

translation.en: But ourselves, you know, we couldn't get out of it.
If you don't do whatever they ask you to do, they kill you right away.
translation.ko: 시키는 대로 하지 않으면 곧장 죽어야 했으니까요

translation.en: One time I had two friends of mine, very close friends of mine.
translation.ko: 아주 친했던 친구들 둘이 들어왔던 적이 있었어요

translation.en: They came in, you know. Their names were the Venezias.
translation.ko: 아주 친했던 친구들 둘이 들어왔던 적이 있었어요 베네치아 가족이었는데

translation.en: And… [clear throat] …I told them right away
that they were going to die.
And they asked for food, and whatever I had, I gave them to eat,
translation.ko: 음식을 달라기에 제가 가진 걸 먹으라고 주면서

translation.en: and I told them exactly where to keep themselves,
where the openings were, so they can die fast.
translation.ko: 빨리 죽을 수 있도록 가스 투입구 위치를 알려줬죠

translation.en: And after they were through, I took them out, and I washed them,
translation.ko: 일이 끝난 후 친구들 시신을 꺼내서 씻고

translation.en: and I put them in the oven to be burned.
[Tom Lantos] We could hear the artillery moving closer and closer.
translation.ko: 포병대가 점점 가까워지는 걸 소리로 느낄 수 있었어요

translation.en: And Budapest was the battlefield between the Germans and the Soviet Army.
And although we knew it would be weeks
before the Soviet Army would hopefully liberate the remaining Jews,
translation.ko: 소련군이 남은 유대인을 해방할 날이 오길 바라면서도

translation.en: we knew that lots of hardships were still ahead.
translation.ko: 고난이 쉽게 끝나지 않으리란 걸 알았어요

translation.en: [Alice Lok Cahana] In Auschwitz, after Christmas,
we heard more and more the bombing came closer and closer.
The Nazis didn't want anybody to get liberated,
translation.ko: 나치는 한 명도 풀어줄 생각이 없었기 때문에

translation.en: so they were herding the people away from the camp.
[Randolph Braham] The death march was in winter.
Those who could not keep pace were simply shot by the wayside.
translation.ko: 속도를 못 따라오는 사람은 길가에서 그대로 총살해 버렸죠

translation.en: If anybody, anybody tries to run away
or do anything that is not permitted, will be shot on the spot.
translation.ko: 허락받지 않은 행동을 하면 그 자리에서 총살했어요

translation.en: There were three of us friends that were together up to that point.
translation.ko: 그때까지 세 친구가 똘똘 뭉쳐 지냈는데

translation.en: But we swore that we would sacrifice each other's life for each other.
translation.ko: 서로를 구하기 위해서라면 목숨을 바치겠다고 맹세했어요

translation.en: We would never let each other down.
Kids. You know, we had this sort of a dream that will be possible.
translation.ko: 어릴 때니까, 할 수 있다는 꿈이 있었죠

translation.en: One of the three had an injury in his knee and had gangrene,
translation.ko: 셋 중 하나가 무릎을 다쳐 괴사가 생겼어요

translation.en: and one of the soldiers noticed him limping.
So, he comes up, and he wants to shoot him.
We step in front of him. He pulls out his Luger and says,
translation.ko: 쫓아와서 쏘려고 하길래 우리가 가로막았어요 군인은 루거 권총을 꺼내며 말했어요

translation.en: "I'll give you till three seconds. Count to three."
translation.ko: 군인은 루거 권총을 꺼내며 말했어요 '3초 주겠다, 셋을 세라'

translation.en: "Either you let him go, or all the three of you die."
Can you imagine, even so young, the decision that we had to make?
translation.ko: 어떤 심정일지 알겠어요? 그 어린 나이에 우리가 내려야 했던 결정을?

translation.en: Here, we promised that we will die for each other,
but we couldn't keep that promise under threat of death.
translation.ko: 죽음의 위협이 다가오자 약속을 지킬 수 없었어요

translation.en: We did let him die.
We arrived… About ten days' march or so, we arrived into Dachau.
[Bill Basch] Oh my God.
After 53 years…
it's as if it were yesterday.
You could find them here on the street, just laying,
translation.ko: 이런 노상에 사람들이 그냥 쓰러져 있었어

translation.en: and you didn't pay attention. You stepped over bodies.
translation.ko: 신경 쓸 겨를도 없이 밟고 지나가야만 했지

translation.en: You didn't pay any attention. It didn't mean anything.
-[Martin] Right here? -Yeah.
I never knew anybody's name.
Never wanted to know anybody.
I never wanted to know, just in case someday
someone will know this person
whose shoes I have taken off when he died.
If you can imagine that every morning, my job was for a while…
translation.ko: 한동안 내가 아침마다 맡았던 일이 있었어

translation.en: I had to go barrack to barrack to barrack
and take those bodies and bring them to the crematorium.
We had one of those push cars.
I remember the Sonderkommandos that worked in the crematorium
came out, and they opened the gate.
They took it over from here and walked it in,
translation.ko: 그 사람들이 여기서 수레를 받아 끌고 갔지

translation.en: but we were never allowed to cross this.
translation.ko: 우린 이 문턱을 절대 넘을 수 없었어

translation.en: They never talked about the crematorium, but we knew.
translation.ko: 아무도 화장장 얘기를 안 했지만 우린 알고 있었어

translation.en: If we walked in here, we never got out.
You never got out from here, from this area.
Because, I mean, if they let him out, and he escapes,
they have witness, they have testimony. So they wouldn't let them out.
translation.ko: 증인이 생기고 증언을 할 테니까 한 명도 살려두지 않았지

translation.en: Look at that.
The inhumanity of man against man…
translation.ko: 인간이 인간에게 이만큼 잔혹할 수 있다는 게

translation.en: is beyond belief.
This is…
the most monstrous thing that man devised.
Burning human beings just, just to get rid of them quicker.
Unbelievable.
Just so emotional. It's so hard.
Now, why did I survive?
Why did God spare me?
Somebody started to yell, "Americans! Americans!"
And we didn't know what they mean by Americans. And they were pointing up to the sky.
translation.ko: 무슨 말인가 어리둥절한데 그 사람들이 하늘을 가리켰어요

translation.en: Planes came out from behind the mountains, from nowhere,
and they just bombed the convoy.
And they they didn't touch us. None of us got hurt.
translation.ko: 우리는 건드리지 않았어요 다친 사람이 하나도 없었죠

translation.en: That's when I found out the first time that the United States was at war.
translation.ko: 미국이 전쟁에 참전했다는 건 그때 처음으로 알았어요

translation.en: It was April 29th when I was ordered to go to Dachau.
translation.ko: 4월 29일에 다하우로 가라는 명령을 받았습니다 "워런 던 미 공군 참전 용사"

translation.en: Actually, the night of the 28th.
And we were ordered to take off as fast as possible to get to Dachau,
translation.ko: 최대한 빨리 출격해 다하우로 가라고 했어요

translation.en: not knowing what we were facing.
We thought it was a military camp,
translation.ko: 우린 거기가 군 주둔지인 줄 알았어요

translation.en: a German military camp that we were going in to take,
translation.ko: "폴 파크스 박사 미 공군 참전 용사" 독일군 주둔지를 점령하러 출격해

translation.en: and therefore we were gonna capture it and capture the people inside.
translation.ko: 기지를 손에 넣고 병력은 생포하는 줄 알았어요

translation.en: We were in the vicinity
of what we found out to be concentration camps.
translation.ko: "카츠고 미호 미 공군 참전 용사" 강제수용소로 판단되는 장소가 있었어요

translation.en: [Bill Basch] Suddenly, we hear machine guns shooting up.
translation.ko: 갑자기 기관총 사격 소리가 들리는 거야

translation.en: First thought was that we are being killed.
Then we saw American soldiers climbing, crawling and shooting.
translation.ko: 그런데 미군이 담을 넘고 포복하며 총을 쏘는 게 보였어

translation.en: Then we saw German soldiers coming from that direction.
And as they met up here in the center, that Germans gave up.
translation.ko: 이 한복판에서 양쪽이 마주치자 독일군이 항복했어

translation.en: But visualize 32,000 people coming out of all those barracks.
translation.ko: 그때 막사에서 32,000명이 뛰쳐나왔다고 상상을 해 봐

translation.en: Outside the camp…
on the railroad tracks was…
40 boxcars, I believe was the count.
Absolutely full of dead bodies.
And not having had any knowledge of what we were facing,
translation.ko: 이곳의 정체를 전혀 모르고 왔던 우리에게

translation.en: this was…
totally unreal.
Most of them wearing flannel pajamas. That's all what they had.
translation.ko: 대부분이 플란넬 잠옷을 입고 있었어요 그거 말곤 없었죠

translation.en: Blue stripe, white stripe. Flannel pajamas.
translation.ko: 파란 줄무늬, 흰 줄무늬 플란넬 잠옷이었어요

translation.en: People were weak.
Weak probably isn't even the right term.
But they were emaciated.
Some looked very old, but they weren't.
[Katsugo Miho] They were walking dead, is what we called them. Skeletons.
[Paul Parks] A few came out first,
then more came out, and more came out,
and they kept coming toward us
because it was almost as if they realized…
I guess they did. They realized that we were different.
translation.ko: 그 사람들 눈에 우리는 다르게 보였나 봐요

translation.en: That we were people coming to help them.
translation.ko: 도우러 온 사람이란 걸 알아봤던 것 같아요

translation.en: And Americans held the gun against the Germans,
but they didn't kill them. They let us have them.
And taking a dozen or so German soldiers that we caught,
literally tore them apart, piece by piece.
We captured a German colonel.
And I went back and told him
that we're going to send you back to the officers to talk to you.
And he spit in my face.
Then I killed him.
It wasn't long before the war was over after that.
But by those last days,
we intended to stop Germany from ever having the opportunity
translation.ko: 우리는 독일이 누구에게도 같은 만행을 저지르지 못하게

translation.en: to stand up again and do this to anybody.
I've seen many a horrible sight
in that two years of… In Italy, France and Germany,
translation.ko: 이탈리아, 프랑스, 독일에 2년간 주둔하면서 끔찍한 광경을 무수히 봤어요

translation.en: but the worst thing I've ever seen in my life
translation.ko: 하지만 제 평생 목격한 최악의 모습은

translation.en: were the survivors of the Holocaust.
This is something which is…
To this day, I cannot forget.
I wasn't young anymore.
I was very old.
I was 16, but I was very old.
Returning to freedom was very difficult.
We didn't know how we're going to make peace with the outside world, which didn't want us.
translation.ko: 우리를 원하지 않았던 바깥세상과 어떻게 타협할 것인지 알지 못했고

translation.en: And we didn't know…
who we're going to find or not find.
translation.ko: 누구를 찾고 누구를 잊어야 할지 몰랐어요

translation.en: They didn't know what to do with us. And they put us in a DP camp,
translation.ko: 우리를 처리할 방법을 못 찾고 DP 캠프에 넣었어요

translation.en: which is a displaced persons camp.
And the closest one from where I was, was in Austria.
translation.ko: 저와 가장 가까운 수용소가 오스트리아에 있었어요

translation.en: And all the survivors that had no other place to go were in that camp.
translation.ko: 갈 곳이 없는 생존자는 전부 그 수용소로 가게 됐죠

translation.en: So it was another camp, but it was free.
After the Soviet Army liberated Budapest,
and I became a free human being again,
I did not know for months
whether my mother or other members of my family would ever return.
translation.ko: 어머니나 다른 가족이 돌아올지 알 수가 없었어요

translation.en: [Renee Firestone] I was hoping that going back to Auschwitz is finally going to give me some closure.
translation.ko: 언젠가는 아우슈비츠로 돌아가 종지부를 찍고 싶었어요

translation.en: And, uh, I was shocked to find out
translation.ko: "르네와 통역 폴란드 아우슈비츠 1 수용소" 하지만 막상 가보니 충격적이었죠

translation.en: that it opened up new questions and new doubts.
I would like to find out about my family.
[in Polish] She'd like to look for information about her and her family.
translation.ko: 가족과 본인 관련 정보를 찾고 계시대요

translation.en: Your name, please?
Renee. R-e-n-e-e.
[Renee Firestone] This is the first time that I decided…
to find some records of my family.
And my sister was Klara.
[translator in Polish] You found something?
Yes, I found something. We can look together.
[in Polish] Please lay the cards down like this.
-Klara. -Klara. My sister.
I found records of my sister, my father, and my own,
translation.ko: 여동생, 아버지 나에 관한 기록을 찾았어요

translation.en: and when I asked about my mother…
uh, the archivist, the historian, told me
that those who were taken from the railroad station
translation.ko: 기록을 담당하는 역사학자 말로는 기차역에서 끌려간 사람들은

translation.en: and killed immediately,
there is no record of those.
[in Polish] Take this upstairs to the archive and ring the bell, okay?
translation.ko: 이걸 위층 자료실에 가져가서 벨을 누르시면 돼요

translation.en: [in Polish] Thank you.
This is a test of blood or, uh, or something medical.
translation.ko: 이건 클라라 바인펠드라는 분의 혈액 검사나 의료 기록이에요

translation.en: Subject of Klara Weinfeld.
I found out that my sister was experimented on,
translation.ko: 동생이 생체 실험을 당했다는 걸 알았어요

translation.en: that they were doing some blood tests on her.
And what does this here all mean?
And he said, "I really don't know."
He says, "Nobody ever asked me."
But there is a Dr. Münch, who was the head of this clinic,
translation.ko: 하지만 이 의료시설의 책임자였던 뮌히 박사가

translation.en: who's still alive."
And then I found out that you're going to interview this man,
and that I may have a chance to ask him what those symbols meant.
translation.ko: 이 표식이 뭔지 물을 기회를 얻을 수 있지 않을까요?

translation.en: [in German] My sister Klara died in Auschwitz…
And I recently obtained these papers from Auschwitz.
translation.ko: 그리고 최근에 아우슈비츠에서 이 서류를 입수했어요

translation.en: -I would like you to explain these papers. -I will try.
translation.ko: - 서류에 관해 설명을 듣고 싶어요 - 노력해 보겠습니다

translation.en: Can you tell me what this is?
[Hans Münch in English] No, nothing important, no.
What kind of experiments were these?
[in German] It's nothing. Everything is good.
translation.ko: 아무 이상 없어요 전부 정상이라고 돼 있어요

translation.en: -Why did she die? -"Clinical Institute."
translation.ko: 사망한 원인은 무엇이었나요? - '임상연구소'라고 돼 있네요? - 맞아요

translation.en: -That's my institute. -Yeah.
-[Hans Münch] She did die. -[Renee] Yeah.
When did she arrive? How long did she stay?
[in English] Six months.
-Six months. -Six months? Yeah, six months.
-[in German] And then she died. -Yeah.
Well, that is the normal period. Do you understand?
You were in Auschwitz as well? Well then, you should know.
translation.ko: 아우슈비츠에 같이 계셨어요? 그럼 무슨 뜻인지 아실 텐데요

translation.en: [Renee Firestone in English] I tried to be civilized,
but he was very evasive,
and I became very angry.
I kept thinking that thousands and thousands of people died in his clinic.
translation.ko: 그 사람 연구소에서 죽어간 수많은 사람들이 떠올랐어요

translation.en: I am going to go back to Crematorium V
because I know that my mother was taken there for sure.
I'm going to light some candles.
translation.ko: 초나 몇 개 켜드려야겠어요 "1932년의 르네와 어머니"

translation.en: And I know that I am not coming back here anymore.
And now…
just very recently,
I got a new letter from Bergen-Belsen
translation.ko: 베르겐 벨젠 수용소로부터 편지를 한 통 받았어요

translation.en: that they don't have Edith Lok. They looked through their books.
translation.ko: 기록을 다 뒤졌지만 이디스 록이란 사람이 없대요

translation.en: But they found an Edith Schwarz.
And I remembered at one point,
my sister Edith decided
that she will use my mother's name, but I forgot it.
translation.ko: 어머니 성을 쓰겠다고 했던 걸 잊어버렸던 거예요

translation.en: And all these years, I looked for Edith Lok.
translation.ko: 그 기나긴 세월을 이디스 록만 찾아다녔어요

translation.en: -Can you find me, though, with Hungarian-- -Hungarian?
Let's just find it. Okay.
-It's not alphabetized. -Yeah?
[Alice Lok Cahana] Going back to Bergen-Belsen,
I want my husband to say a prayer with my children and with me
translation.ko: 남편, 아이들과 함께 기도를 올리고 싶었어요

translation.en: because we will symbolically bury Edith.
This is the cemetery where all the people were buried
who were brought after liberation to the military blocks.
translation.ko: 해방 후 군사 기지에서 모셔온 분들이죠

translation.en: We found the name of your sister.
She died here.
We think at the 2nd of June, 1945.
So, all the people who died in those days were buried here, one beside the next one.
translation.ko: 그 시기에 돌아가신 분들은 모두 여기 나란히 묻히셨어요

translation.en: [Alice Lok Cahana] Today is the most special day of my life.
translation.ko: 오늘은 내 인생에서 가장 특별한 날이에요

translation.en: Finally, the search is over.
And we now know what happened, and when it happened.
translation.ko: 이제는 어떤 일이 있었고 언제 돌아가셨는지 알아요

translation.en: I brought here my mother's prayer book,
and here we will say for you
the prayers that's traditional
and light this candle in your memory.
And remember… [clears throat]… you…
forever…
as long as we live.
[Alice Lok Cahana] But there are a lot of people like me out there,
who are still looking.
Because for us…
liberation was not the last day.
[Tom Lantos] I got an announcement that I'd been selected
to receive an academic scholarship
to the University of Washington, in a town called "Seattle,"
translation.ko: 워싱턴대학교에서 장학금을 받게 됐다고요 '시틀'이란 도시에 있다고 했어요

translation.en: because nobody told me it's supposed to be pronounced "Seattle."
translation.ko: '시애틀'로 읽는 게 맞다는 걸 아무도 알려주지 않았죠

translation.en: I had a ticket on the SS Marine Falcon.
I went to bunk B-20, put down my knapsack, and they called for chow.
translation.ko: B-20 침상에 내 배낭을 놓자 짬 먹으라고 부르더군요

translation.en: I had no idea what chow was. It wasn't part of my English vocabulary.
translation.ko: 짬이 뭔지 몰랐어요 처음 듣는 영어 단어였죠

translation.en: So, I got into the chow line.
We had these huge metal trays, and this was a period
translation.ko: 커다란 철제 쟁반을 썼는데 그때까지도 저는

translation.en: when, of course, my mental preoccupation was still with hunger.
translation.ko: 커다란 철제 쟁반을 썼는데 그때까지도 저는 굶주림이 뇌에 각인된 상태였죠

translation.en: And these wonderful people slopped on wonderful things on this metal tray.
translation.ko: 그런데 이 멋있는 양반들이 온갖 산해진미를 쟁반에 퍼 줬고

translation.en: And at the end of the line,
there was a huge wicker basket of oranges.
A huge wicker basket of bananas.
translation.ko: 바나나 한가득 든 커다란 바구니가 있었죠

translation.en: My mother always taught me to do the right thing.
And I didn't know what right was. So there was another huge sailor,
translation.ko: 뭐가 바른 건지 모르겠길래 덩치 큰 수병에게 물었어요

translation.en: and I asked him, "Sir, do I take a banana?"
translation.ko: 덩치 큰 수병에게 물었어요 '바나나를 가져가도 됩니까?'

translation.en: "Or do I take an orange?"
And he said, "You eat all the damn bananas and all the damn oranges you want."
translation.ko: 그랬더니 바나나든, 오렌지든 마음껏 퍼다 먹으래요

translation.en: And then I knew I was in heaven.
[Irene Zisblatt] I loved my town, and I see it picturesque and happy.
translation.ko: 난 우리 고향이 좋았어요 그림처럼 예쁘고 행복한 곳이죠

translation.en: I'm planning to go there for the first time since I left in 1944.
Look at the sign, Robin. It says "Polyana" in Russian.
translation.ko: 저기 표지판 봐라, 로빈 러시아어로 '폴랴나'라고 돼 있어

translation.en: You see?
The river is running on the right.
We used to go bathing here…
I'm hoping that I can find some of the people that I knew
before the Holocaust…
and maybe that I can talk to them.
-Mushrooms in the jar. See? -Yes.
[Irene in English] Maybe they can tell me things that happened while we were away.
translation.ko: 우리가 없는 사이에 있었던 일을 들을 수 있겠죠

translation.en: [Irene] This one woman, Mariska, she remembered my grandparents
translation.ko: 마리슈카라는 할머니 한 분이 우리 조부모님과

translation.en: and my father and my mother and me.
I was most surprised that she remembered me.
I was really afraid that the people were going to be hostile to me,
translation.ko: 적대적으로 대하면 어쩌나 몹시 걱정하고 갔어요

translation.en: that they were going to be accusing me of coming back to take something from them.
translation.ko: 뭔가 빼앗을 속셈으로 돌아왔다고 생각할 수 있으니까요

translation.en: I was asked in a very nice way,
"Am I planning to take my property and come back to live there?"
translation.ko: 혹시 내 땅을 되찾고 돌아와서 살 계획이냐고요

translation.en: And I said no.
I just want my children to know where I come from,
and I wanted to see my town where I grew up once more before I die.
translation.ko: 죽기 전에 내가 자란 마을을 다시 보고 싶을 뿐이라고 했죠

translation.en: [Renee Firestone] Going back to my hometown
with my family, with my child,
showing her this beautiful town, which…
translation.ko: "우크라이나 우즈호로드 과거 헝가리" 이 아름다운 도시를 보여줬어요

translation.en: Everywhere we went, the word "Jew" doesn't exist.
translation.ko: 어디를 가도 '유대'란 말은 남아 있지 않았어요

translation.en: This building was the Jewish community center.
I wanted to go to the Jewish temple, which was a beautiful synagogue.
translation.ko: 유대교 회당에 가고 싶었어요 아름다운 사원이었죠

translation.en: Look, look, look how they let this…
Oh my God.
What they did to this city, you just have no idea.
translation.ko: 이 도시에 무슨 짓을 한 건지 이해할 수가 없어

translation.en: It's just unbelievable.
We went to the temple,
and there I met this man, this Jewish man.
He was also in Auschwitz.
[in Hungarian] Hello, do you speak Hungarian?
[Renee] Good morning. Are you from here?
I was born here in 1928.
[Renee] I'm from the Weinfeld family.
Weinfeld?
[Renee] My father had a shop on Cobbler's Lane.
And of course, my mother attended this temple.
I had my Bar Mitzvah here when I turned 13, in 1941.
And why did you stay here?
Because I came back from Auschwitz
on June 6, 1945.
And a few days later, the borders were closed.
[Renee in English] Then he walked us through the temple, and he explained to us
that this is no longer a Jewish temple.
[man in Hungarian] In the old days, there were Stars of David here.
translation.ko: 옛날에는 다윗의 별이 이 자리에 있었죠

translation.en: [Renee] What did they do with them?
[man] They made it into a concert hall.
They removed everything.
[Renee Firestone in English] It was very painful to see
that this holy place was transformed into a place of entertainment.
The most difficult part was going back to my house.
translation.ko: "르네와 남편 버나드, 딸 클라라" 무엇보다 힘들었던 건 제가 살던 집에 가보는 거였죠

translation.en: Oh my God!
That's the… the original… That's the original gate.
-The entrance. -The entrance, yeah.
It was neglected.
This beautiful house that my father took care of always.
translation.ko: 아버지가 정성껏 가꿨던 그 아름다운 집이 말이죠

translation.en: And everything was manicured around it.
-[Bernard] I think that's locked. -[Renee] No.
No, it isn't.
-It just doesn't open. -[Klara] Can we go?
translation.ko: - 그냥 안 열리는 거야 - 그만 가죠

translation.en: [Renee] It doesn't open.
At that moment, I really wished I wouldn't have seen it.
translation.ko: 차라리 못 본 걸로 기억에서 지우고 싶었어요

translation.en: One of the neighbors
who was a young child at the time they took us away was still there.
Thank God that you are still alive.
I'm telling you, I can still remember everything as it used to be.
translation.ko: 난 지금도 옛날 일이 고스란히 기억나요

translation.en: [Renee in English] He has now a Russian wife
who was very sympathetic.
[in Hungarian] Your own house…
To take someone's house, how could that be?
translation.ko: 남의 집을 가로채다니 어떻게 그럴 수가 있죠?

translation.en: There would be a lot to tell, but you know what they say…
translation.ko: 하고픈 얘기는 너무 많지만 곤란한 거 아시죠?

translation.en: Even the walls have ears.
[Renee in English] She was scared to tell me what really happened after we left.
translation.ko: 우리가 떠난 후에 있었던 일을 말하기 두려워했어요

translation.en: [in Hungarian] Tell me, after we were taken, did you talk about it?
translation.ko: 우리가 끌려간 후 우리 얘기 한 적 있어요?

translation.en: We were so sorry for Klara. We heard she died on the way.
translation.ko: 클라라가 너무 안쓰러웠죠 가는 길에 돌아가셨다고 들었어요

translation.en: No. She died there.
Poor thing.
I have only seen it in the movies.
Did they really burn people like that?
Unfortunately, it was much worse than what they show in the movies.
translation.ko: 안타깝지만 영화에 나온 것보다 훨씬 더 끔찍했어요

translation.en: [Renee in English] At that moment, I felt very lucky,
that I would have a chance to go back to the United States, to my home.
translation.ko: 난 미국의 집으로 돌아갈 기회가 있었으니까요

translation.en: I saved the diamonds all the way, through the whole… everything.
translation.ko: 난 그 세월 동안 다이아몬드를 지켜냈어요

translation.en: And when I was free, I, uh, didn't talk about the Holocaust,
translation.ko: 자유를 얻은 후 "1945년의 이레네" 홀로코스트 얘기는 일절 하지 않았지만

translation.en: but I took the diamonds, and I mounted them into a teardrop-shaped pendant,
translation.ko: 눈물방울 모양 펜던트에 그 다이아몬드를 박았어요

translation.en: because every time I had to save them, I had to cry so much.
translation.ko: 다이아몬드를 되찾을 때마다 너무 많이 울었거든요

translation.en: So, I felt that the tears are appropriate for that.
And I told my children that these diamonds should go down
from generation to generation,
to the first-born girl in the family, until forever.
…what it tastes like. [chuckles]
And you can see their different shapes and different cuts.
And they're the only thing that I…
…that I'm holding that my mother ever held.
Okay, well. I don't know what you think about…
My life today is something I myself cannot believe.
translation.ko: 난 지금 스스로도 믿지 못할 인생을 살고 있어요

translation.en: Having been elected by my constituents in California of some 600,000 people,
nine times,
it all seems like a dream.
And it all places
an incredible sense of responsibility on me…
As the only survivor of the Holocaust
translation.ko: 홀로코스트 생존자로 유일하게 미국 하원에 선출된 의원으로서

translation.en: ever elected to the Congress of the United States,
translation.ko: 홀로코스트 생존자로 유일하게 미국 하원에 선출된 의원으로서 "톰 랜토스 하원의원"

translation.en: I know I speak for all of my colleagues,
Republicans and Democrats,
in expressing our outrage at the most recent terrorist attacks…
translation.ko: 최근 발생한 테러 공격에 분노를 표하며…

translation.en: The central focus of my life, obviously, is human rights
because I am convinced that this is really the path
translation.ko: 인권을 수호하는 것이 더 문명화된 사회로 가는

translation.en: of a more civilized world.
My wife Annette and I have known each other all our lives.
translation.ko: 제 아내 애넷과 저는 평생의 친구입니다

translation.en: We grew up as children in Budapest.
translation.ko: 어린 시절 부다페스트에서 함께 자란 사이고

translation.en: And we have been married now for 47 years.
We have two daughters
who early on came to us and said
that, uh… they plan a special gift for their parents.
translation.ko: 엄마, 아빠한테 특별할 선물을 안겨줄 계획이라고요

translation.en: [Tom] Since our families were wiped out, they will give us a large family.
translation.ko: 가족을 몰살당한 우리 부부에게 대가족을 선사하겠다고 했어요

translation.en: And we have been blessed with 17 wonderful grandchildren,
and it's really the focus of our life.
[Renee Firestone] I would like to be known as an educator on the Holocaust.
So I go to the Museum of Tolerance,
where I was the founder of the outreach program.
And I speak to groups who come into the Museum.
…came into being.
You know, when these things are happening,
you almost begin to believe that you did something wrong.
translation.ko: 내가 뭘 잘못했나 자책부터 하게 돼요

translation.en: Why would they do this to me?
I feel that it is my duty
to make the world aware of what happened during that time.
translation.ko: 그 시기에 벌어진 만행을 세상에 알려야 하죠

translation.en: I always felt that my language is inadequate.
translation.ko: 제 언어로는 한계가 있다고 언제나 느꼈어요

translation.en: And that if I wanted to tell the story about my experiences,
I have to talk through a medium.
And I found art
because art transcends.
It's beyond words.
I wanted the surface to be very much layered.
It should look like a crumbled wall,
like it's papered over with yesterday's news
because people want to forget the past.
People want to forget about the Holocaust.
What keeps me going is really…
the family…
that my husband and I created.
My grandchildren.
Three wonderful children.
Two of them rabbis.
And my beautiful daughter.
She teaches me every day what is important in life.
translation.ko: 인생에서 중요한 게 뭔지 매일 제게 가르침을 줘요

translation.en: And my husband, who is four generations Israeli.
translation.ko: 그리고 이스라엘계 4세인 남편도 빠뜨릴 수 없죠

translation.en: And such a gallant man.
And he helped me to construct a life.
translation.ko: 남편은 제가 인생을 구상하는데 도움을 줬어요

translation.en: This painting is Arbeit Macht Frei.
translation.ko: 이 그림 제목은 '노동이 그대를 자유케 하리라'

translation.en: When you read this welcome gate,
so to speak, Arbeit macht frei…
My art today is about the Holocaust
because I have no memorial for my people.
translation.ko: 내 사람들을 위한 묘비를 못 세웠거든요

translation.en: I… don't know where they are.
Why so many of my family members died, so many got killed.
translation.ko: 어째서 수많은 우리 가족이 죽고 처형당해야 했을까요?

translation.en: The Basch family was almost wiped out.
We have regenerated.
So when we get together, we are quite a large group.
translation.ko: 그래서 가족이 모이면 이제 숫자가 상당해요

translation.en: And the joy sitting with my family
translation.ko: 내 가족과 함께 둘러앉을 수 있어 기뻐요

translation.en: and looking around and saying that I was so close to death.
translation.ko: 눈을 마주치며 난 거의 죽다 살아났다고 말하죠

translation.en: And here I am sitting at a table, and there are 11, 12 of us,
rejoicing life.
The pleasure of living is wonderful.
translation.ko: 살아서 느끼는 즐거움은 이루 말할 수 없습니다

translation.en: One day, it was on a Sunday, someone knocked at my door
translation.ko: 아마도 일요일이었을 겁니다 누가 문을 두드렸어요

translation.en: and walked into…
And I went to the door.
And they had something wrapped up in a newspaper under the arm.
translation.ko: 뭔가를 신문지로 싸서 팔에 끼고 왔어요

translation.en: He said, "You Paul Parks?" I said, "Yes."
He said, "We've been looking for you for several years."
"Off-and-on, people have been looking."
"We wanted to find you." I said, "Why?"
He said, "There was a fellow liberated by you guys at Dachau who remembered you."
translation.ko: '다하우에서 선생님께 구출됐다는 기억을 가진 분이 계셨거든요'

translation.en: "And he died several years ago."
"And he'd made a menorah in the camp."
"He made it out of concrete nails
and welded it and braided it together while he was in the camp."
"And he wants you to… He wanted you to have it."
"So we've been looking to give it to you. Here it is."
And he gave me this beautiful menorah.
translation.ko: 그러더니 이 아름다운 메노라 촛대를 줬어요

translation.en: [Irene Zisblatt] Liberation was like a present from the world.
And that's the first time I acknowledged God again,
translation.ko: 그때가 돼서야 하느님의 존재를 다시 받아들였죠

translation.en: that He is around, and He helped me to get to this point.
translation.ko: 우리 주변에 계시며 이 자리에 오도록 이끄셨다고요

translation.en: I don't think that God created the Holocaust.
I think that God gave us a mind and a heart and a free will.
translation.ko: 신은 우리에게 정신과 마음과 자유 의지를 주셨죠

translation.en: And it is up to man…
what he's going to do with his life.
And I blame man, not God.
I cannot rationally explain…
emotionally explain, intellectually explain the Holocaust.
translation.ko: 이성적, 감정적, 지성적으로 설명할 길이 없어요

translation.en: I cannot… I cannot find…
a place for…
a higher authority
in this nightmare.
What kind of people are we?
What are the books teaching us?
What is the difference between me…
and another child?
What is the Bible teaching me?
What… What is this about?
[Randolph Braham] Hitler remained a pathological anti-Semite to the end.
translation.ko: 히틀러는 병적인 반유대주의를 끝까지 버리지 못했어요

translation.en: And one of his last testaments,
or warnings to his followers,
was for them to continue the war against the Jews.
In his will executed April 29, 1945,
he says, "Above all,
I enjoin the government and the people
to uphold the race laws to the limit,
and to resist mercilessly
the poisoner of all nations,
international Jewry."
[Randolph Braham] The Holocaust has to be thought as a chapter
in the long history of man's inhumanity to man.
translation.ko: 유구한 역사 중 하나의 장으로 기억돼야 합니다

translation.en: One cannot ignore
the discrimination
inflicted on many people
because of race, color, or creed.
One cannot ignore slavery.
One cannot ignore the burning of witches.
One cannot ignore the killing of Christians in the Roman period.
translation.ko: 로마 시대 기독교도 몰살도 잊어선 안 되고요

translation.en: The Holocaust perhaps is the culmination
of the kind of horror that can occur
when man loses his integrity,
translation.ko: 인간 생명의 존엄성에 관한 신념을 잃었을 때

translation.en: his belief in the sanctity of human life.
translation.ko: 일어날 수 있는 참상의 정점일지도 모릅니다
